articles.headline: Ford Tries to Save the Lincoln Brand
articles.snippet: Sales of Ford’s luxury nameplate peaked in 1990 at more than 200,000 vehicles, but by last year only 85,643 were sold.
articles.abstract: Sales of Ford’s luxury nameplate peaked in 1990 at more than 200,000 vehicles, but by last year only 85,643 were sold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ford Motor, alone among America’s Big Three automakers, staved off bankruptcy and survived the financial crisis. Its sales, profit and stock price have surged. Now it faces what may be an even tougher challenge: Can it save its faltering Lincoln brand?

articles.headline: Russian Lender Building Its Own Bloc in Eastern Europe
articles.snippet: An acquisition campaign that expands Sberbank in eight Eastern European countries might seem like a banker’s version of rebuilding the old Soviet bloc.
articles.abstract: An acquisition campaign that expands Sberbank in eight Eastern European countries might seem like a banker’s version of rebuilding the old Soviet bloc.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The motto of the Russian state-owned bank Sberbank is “always nearby.” Its branches, adorned with a cheery green-and-white logo, are truly ubiquitous in its home market.

articles.headline: Fatal Collision Makes Car-Sharing Worries No Longer Theoretical
articles.snippet: A fatal accident in Boston has exposed the liability car owners can face when they offer to rent their cars through companies like RelayRides.
articles.abstract: A fatal accident in Boston has exposed the liability car owners can face when they offer to rent their cars through companies like RelayRides.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, I wrote about RelayRides, a company that helps you rent your car to strangers. It’s a big enough idea that the company has attracted investments from Google and General Motors.

articles.headline: Diamonds as a Commodity
articles.snippet: Some investment professionals are competing to turn the gem into a commodity that would become available to investors in exchange-traded funds the way gold has in recent years.
articles.abstract: Some investment professionals are competing to turn the gem into a commodity that would become available to investors in exchange-traded funds the way gold has in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Could diamonds be the new gold?

articles.headline: The Provocateur
articles.snippet: The conservative blogger Andrew Breitbart died just as he was building his own mini-empire of conservative opinion and infotainment.
articles.abstract: The conservative blogger Andrew Breitbart died just as he was building his own mini-empire of conservative opinion and infotainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON the last night of February, Arthur Sando was having a drink at the Brentwood Restaurant and Lounge in Los Angeles when a bearded silver-haired man took a seat next to him, ordered a glass of pinot noir and began typing into his BlackBerry.

articles.headline: Behind Instagram’s Success, Networking the Old Way
articles.snippet: The founders of Instagram, now multimillionaires after Facebook bought their app this week, were helped along the way by the tight web in the Bay Area tech scene.
articles.abstract: The founders of Instagram, now multimillionaires after Facebook bought their app this week, were helped along the way by the tight web in the Bay Area tech scene.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Past midnight, in a dimly lighted warehouse jutting into the San Francisco Bay, Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger introduced something they had been working on for weeks: a photo-sharing iPhone application called Instagram. What happened next was crazier than they could have imagined.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta, Nicole Perlroth and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: In California, Economic Gap of East vs. West
articles.snippet: Along the coast, communities have largely bounced back from the recession, but inland areas are still struggling with high unemployment and a persistent housing crisis.
articles.abstract: Along the coast, communities have largely bounced back from the recession, but inland areas are still struggling with high unemployment and a persistent housing crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — For decades, California has been seen nationally and by its own residents as a state divided into north and south, urbane tree-huggers versus car-obsessed beach hoppers. But the more meaningful division, it turns out, may be between east and west.

articles.headline: Unexpected Ally Helps Wal-Mart Cut Waste
articles.snippet: The company, the nation’s biggest retailer, worked with the Environmental Defense Fund in setting policies that would help the company reuse and recycle most of its waste.
articles.abstract: The company, the nation’s biggest retailer, worked with the Environmental Defense Fund in setting policies that would help the company reuse and recycle most of its waste.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michelle Harvey, an employee of the Environmental Defense Fund, has a security badge to a site that used to be considered enemy territory: the headquarters of Wal-Mart Stores in Bentonville, Ark.

articles.headline: Resurgent Beirut Offers Haven Amid Turmoil of Arab Spring
articles.snippet: For Lebanese content to stay out of the storm, and for Arab visitors seeking respite from fear and uncertainty around the region, Beirut is a destination to enjoy life.
articles.abstract: For Lebanese content to stay out of the storm, and for Arab visitors seeking respite from fear and uncertainty around the region, Beirut is a destination to enjoy life.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Down a ramp from Beirut’s clamorous seaside road, motor yachts bob along a curving waterfront promenade. Tablecloths gleam white, and bottles of wine sweat in silver coolers. The boardwalk’s rough planks, a nod to maritime authenticity, present a design flaw perhaps foreseeable in this city: Women with Louis Vuitton handbags are forever extracting their spike heels from the cracks.

articles.headline: Nigeria Tested by Rapid Rise in Population
articles.snippet: Much of the Earth’s population growth is in sub-Saharan African nations like Nigeria, where trends that have lowered birthrates elsewhere have not yet caught on.
articles.abstract: Much of the Earth’s population growth is in sub-Saharan African nations like Nigeria, where trends that have lowered birthrates elsewhere have not yet caught on.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — In a quarter-century, at the rate Nigeria is growing, 300 million people — a population about as big as that of the present-day United States — will live in a country roughly the size of Arizona, New Mexico and Nevada. In this commercial hub, where the area’s population has by some estimates nearly doubled over 15 years to 21 million, living standards for many are falling.

articles.headline: Authorities Bar 3 Leading Candidates in Egypt Race
articles.snippet: Egyptian election authorities eliminated the three presidential candidates in an unexpected decision that threw the contest into disarray once again.
articles.abstract: Egyptian election authorities eliminated the three presidential candidates in an unexpected decision that threw the contest into disarray once again.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian election authorities eliminated three of the country’s leading presidential candidates in one broad stroke on Saturday night in an unexpected decision that once again threw into disarray the contest to shape the future of Egypt after the ouster of Hosni Mubarak.

articles.headline: Muslims on Wall Street, Bridging Two Traditions
articles.snippet: A growing number of Muslims are trying to find their path through the rough-and-tumble world of finance — an environment that can often test their values and practices.
articles.abstract: A growing number of Muslims are trying to find their path through the rough-and-tumble world of finance — an environment that can often test their values and practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIEL IQBAL’S co-workers couldn’t figure him out.

articles.headline: How the Tech Parade Passed Sony By
articles.snippet: Sony once wowed the world with the Walkman and the Trinitron TV. But its fortunes have taken a sharp turn amid disruptive new technologies and unforeseen rivals.
articles.abstract: Sony once wowed the world with the Walkman and the Trinitron TV. But its fortunes have taken a sharp turn amid disruptive new technologies and unforeseen rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO

articles.headline: Luxury Stores Pull Out Mandarin Phrase Books to Make the Sale
articles.snippet: Chinese shoppers attracted by lower prices spend more on luxury products abroad than they do at home, and retailers are looking to cash in.
articles.abstract: Chinese shoppers attracted by lower prices spend more on luxury products abroad than they do at home, and retailers are looking to cash in.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over five days in January, a group of visitors to New York was treated to a private concert with the pianist Lang Lang at the Montblanc store, cocktails and a fashion show attended by the designers Oscar de la Renta and Diane Von Furstenberg, and a tour of Estée Lauder’s original office.

articles.headline: NATO Sees Flaws in Air Campaign Against Qaddafi
articles.snippet: The findings undercut the idea that NATO could effectively carry out a more complicated campaign in Syria without relying disproportionately on the United States military.
articles.abstract: The findings undercut the idea that NATO could effectively carry out a more complicated campaign in Syria without relying disproportionately on the United States military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite widespread praise in Western capitals for NATO’s leadership of the air campaign in Libya, a confidential NATO assessment paints a sobering portrait of the alliance’s ability to carry out such campaigns without significant support from the United States.

articles.headline: Google Is Faulted for Impeding U.S. Inquiry on Data Collection
articles.snippet: Federal regulators ordered a $25,000 fine on the search giant, saying it “deliberately impeded” an investigation into the sweeping up of personal data by cars being used to map streets.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators ordered a $25,000 fine on the search giant, saying it “deliberately impeded” an investigation into the sweeping up of personal data by cars being used to map streets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Google first revealed in 2010 that cars it was using to map streets were also sweeping up sensitive personal information from wireless home networks, it called the data collection a mistake. On Saturday, federal regulators charged that Google had “deliberately impeded and delayed” an investigation into the data collection and ordered a $25,000 fine on the search giant.

articles.headline: White House Opens Door to Big Donors, and Lobbyists Slip In
articles.snippet: A cross-reference of donor lists and visitor logs show that of those who gave $100,000 or more, about three-quarters of them visited the White House.
articles.abstract: A cross-reference of donor lists and visitor logs show that of those who gave $100,000 or more, about three-quarters of them visited the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last May, as a battle was heating up between Internet companies and Hollywood over how to stop online piracy, a top entertainment industry lobbyist landed a meeting at the White House with one of President Obama’s technology advisers.
articles.byline: By Mike McIntire and Michael Luo

articles.headline: 100 Tornadoes in 24 Hours, but Plenty of Notice
articles.snippet: Some officials credited a warning system for the relatively small number of injuries and deaths from unrelenting storms over the weekend in the Midwest.
articles.abstract: Some officials credited a warning system for the relatively small number of injuries and deaths from unrelenting storms over the weekend in the Midwest.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOODWARD, Okla. — The tornadoes were unrelenting — more than 100 in 24 hours over a stretch of the Plains states. They tossed vehicles and ripped through homes. They drove families to their basements and whipped debris across small towns throughout the Midwest. In some areas, baseball-size hail rained from the sky.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Complex Attack by Taliban Sends Message to the West
articles.snippet: Suicide bombers and gunmen struck the Afghan capital and three provinces in a clear attempt to erode confidence in NATO and Afghan military gains.
articles.abstract: Suicide bombers and gunmen struck the Afghan capital and three provinces in a clear attempt to erode confidence in NATO and Afghan military gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban suicide bombers and gunmen barraged the diplomatic quarter and the Parliament in the Afghan capital for hours on Sunday and struck three eastern provinces as well, in a complex attack clearly designed to undermine confidence in NATO and Afghan military gains.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin, Graham Bowley and Sangar Rahimi

articles.headline: With Italy and Spain, Further Tests for Europe
articles.snippet: The gloom over the Continent had seemed to be lifting, but a jump in borrowing costs for two countries signaled clearly that the euro’s problems are far from solved.
articles.abstract: The gloom over the Continent had seemed to be lifting, but a jump in borrowing costs for two countries signaled clearly that the euro’s problems are far from solved.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Is the euro crisis back with a vengeance, or do investors have a needless case of anxiety?

articles.headline: Daring to Cut Off Amazon
articles.snippet: In February, the Educational Development Corporation said it would remove its titles from Amazon, more evidence of the tumult over who gets to decide how much a book costs.
articles.abstract: In February, the Educational Development Corporation said it would remove its titles from Amazon, more evidence of the tumult over who gets to decide how much a book costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — Plenty of people are upset at Amazon these days, but it took a small publishing company whose best-known volume is a toilet-training tome to give the mighty Internet store the boot.

articles.headline: Book Publishing’s Real Nemesis
articles.snippet: An antitrust suit may provide short-term price reductions on e-books, but once the competition is flattened, Amazon is likely to resume its monopolistic ways.
articles.abstract: An antitrust suit may provide short-term price reductions on e-books, but once the competition is flattened, Amazon is likely to resume its monopolistic ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department finally took aim at the monopolistic monolith that threatened to dominate the book industry. So imagine the shock when the bullet aimed at threats to competition went whizzing by Amazon — which not long ago had a 90 percent stranglehold on e-books — and instead, struck five of the six biggest publishers and Apple, a minor player in the realm of books.

articles.headline: News Corporation’s Pursuer Had Modest Start
articles.snippet: Mark Lewis, 47, from Manchester, England, is one of a small handful of lawyers who have led the civil litigation against News Corporation over suspected phone hacking.
articles.abstract: Mark Lewis, 47, from Manchester, England, is one of a small handful of lawyers who have led the civil litigation against News Corporation over suspected phone hacking.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch has made a career of painting his critics as elitist, privileged and out of touch. But the English lawyer who stands at the center of the legal battles that have engulfed his News Corporation did not attend a select law school or work at a top London law firm.

articles.headline: Declining as a Manufacturer, Japan Weighs Reinvention
articles.snippet: Many Japanese have a sense that their country has outgrown an economic template based on constructing commodity goods, but they disagree over what should replace it.
articles.abstract: Many Japanese have a sense that their country has outgrown an economic template based on constructing commodity goods, but they disagree over what should replace it.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMAGASAKI, Japan — A few years ago, the densely built-up coastal region around this port was called Panel Bay because of its concentration of factories making the sophisticated flat-panel screens that were symbols of Japan’s manufacturing prowess. But now the area has become a grim symbol of its industrial decline.

articles.headline: Many U.S. Immigrants’ Children Seek American Dream Abroad
articles.snippet: As opportunities expand in countries like China and India, a growing number of well-educated Americans are emigrating to their ancestral homelands.
articles.abstract: As opportunities expand in countries like China and India, a growing number of well-educated Americans are emigrating to their ancestral homelands.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samir N. Kapadia seemed to be on the rise in Washington, moving from an internship on Capitol Hill to jobs at a major foundation and a consulting firm. Yet his days, he felt, had become routine.

articles.headline: Obama Camp, Seeing Shift, Bets on Long Shot in Arizona
articles.snippet: The obstacles for President Obama in Arizona are considerable, but his aides say a victory is possible in a state that analysts believe is heading Democratic.
articles.abstract: The obstacles for President Obama in Arizona are considerable, but his aides say a victory is possible in a state that analysts believe is heading Democratic.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — President Obama’s re-election campaign is dispatching workers across Arizona’s college campuses and Latino neighborhoods this spring, registering as many new voters as they can in an organized, three-month effort to determine whether they can put this unlikely state into play for Democrats this November.

articles.headline: Unanswered Questions in F.C.C.’s Google Case
articles.snippet: An investigation into Google’s Street View project was left unresolved because the engineer in charge declined to talk, according to an interim report.
articles.abstract: An investigation into Google’s Street View project was left unresolved because the engineer in charge declined to talk, according to an interim report.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the most audacious projects ever to come out of Google was the plan to photograph and map the inhabited world, one block at a time. But a report over the weekend from federal regulators has rekindled questions over exactly what the company was doing — questions the search giant has spent years trying not to answer.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Edward Wyatt

articles.headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers and Romney Face a Delicate Tango
articles.snippet: House Republicans said that Mitt Romney could go his own way on smaller issues if elected, but that he must understand they are driving the party’s policy agenda.
articles.abstract: House Republicans said that Mitt Romney could go his own way on smaller issues if elected, but that he must understand they are driving the party’s policy agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If Mitt Romney is considering a quick pivot to the center as he heads into the general election, he will find an imposing impediment: fellow Republicans in the House.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Jennifer Steinhauer
